briefOverview: Judith offers a fervent, penitential prayer asking God to overthrow the Assyrians and to accomplish this through her planned stratagem, affirming that God saves the weak rather than the mighty.
summary: At the hour of evening incense, Judith prostrates herself in ashes and sackcloth and cries to the God of her ancestor Simeon, recalling God’s past judgment on those who violated Israel’s honor. She affirms God’s foreknowledge and rule over history, contrasting divine power with the Assyrians’ reliance on military strength. Judith asks God to cast down the enemy who seeks to defile the sanctuary and altar, and to grant her—a widow—the power she has conceived. She petitions that her speech and planned deceit become the enemy’s wound so that both rulers and servants fall. Confessing that God aids the oppressed and not the numerous or strong, she prays that all nations learn there is no protector of Israel but God.
externalContext: Within Judith’s narrative, the Assyrian general Holofernes has advanced under King Nebuchadnezzar to subdue the western regions, and the Jewish town of Bethulia is under dire threat. Judith’s prayer precedes her deliberate, risky plan to enter the enemy camp and confront Holofernes. The mention of evening incense presumes the Jerusalem temple cult is active, situating the story’s liturgical frame even as the book itself blends historical motifs (e.g., “Assyrians” under Nebuchadnezzar) for theological effect.
externalReferences: Judith’s appeal to “the God of my father Simeon” and the description of a maiden’s violation recall the vengeance taken for Dinah in Genesis 34:25–31. The plea to “break down their stateliness by the hand of a woman” evokes Jael’s slaying of Sisera (Judges 4:17–22; celebrated in Judges 5:24–27). Her affirmation that God does not save by multitude echoes 1 Samuel 14:6 and the principle of Zechariah 4:6 (“not by might, nor by power”). The contrast with trust in horses and military hardware parallels Psalm 20:7 and the Exodus tradition of God overthrowing horse and chariot (Exodus 15:1, 4).

sectionTitles.title: Appeal to God’s deeds and rule
Petition to fell the proud by a woman

practicalQuestions: Where am I tempted to trust in numbers, status, or resources rather than in God’s help?
How might careful, courageous planning and earnest prayer work together in confronting injustice?
What safeguards my zeal for sacred things from becoming personal vengeance or pride?
How do I discern when strategic speech is prudent versus when it becomes unethical deceit?
In what ways can overlooked or underestimated people become instruments of deliverance today?
uncertainAreas: The identification of “my father Simeon” likely invokes the tribal ancestor and Genesis 34 episode, but the exact nuance of the reference is debated. The moral framing of Judith’s requested “deceit” is complex; the text treats it as a just wartime stratagem to protect covenant and sanctuary, yet broader ethical conclusions are not explicit. The book’s use of “Assyrians” under Nebuchadnezzar is historically anachronistic within the narrative, functioning theologically rather than chronologically.
